Sample formulas for derived variables

Example 1: HR vs PULSE

x = IF ([HR] > [PULSE], [HR], [PULSE])

If Heart Rate is greater than Pulse, then x equals Heart Rate; if not, x equals Pulse.

Example 2: Body Surface Area (BSA)

x = IF ( [Weight] < 10, [Weight] ^ 0.75 * 0.09224, IF ( [Weight] <= 29.99, [Weight] ^ 0.66 * 0.09837, IF ( ISEMPTY (HEIGHT), HEIGHT, [Weight] ^ 0.425 * HEIGHT ^ 0.725 * 0.007184) ) )

 

*Note that your hospital unit may use a different formula for BSA.

If Weight is less than 10 kg, x = (Weight ^ 0.75) * 0.09224.

If Weight is less than 29.99 kg, x = (Weight ^ 0.66) * 0.09837.

Note that these expressions do not contradict each other because they are calculated from left to right and the second expression is only used if the first is false. The second expression really means “If Weight is between 10 kg and 29.99 kg.”

If Weight is greater than 29.99 kg, and a value of Height is not available, x = Height = null.

If Weight is greater than 29.99 kg, and a value of Height is available, x = (Weight ^ 0.425) * (Height ^ 0.725) * 0.007184.

Note that Weight appears in brackets because it is a real-time variable; Height does not because it is a database constant.

Example 3: Derived Patient Tidal Volume (dPTV)

dPTV = [RMVout] – ( [Vrate] * ( [TVset] / 1000 ) ) /
( [Rsp_m] – [Vrate]
